paragraphs.text: Since the movie title is in fact the direct and only answer to our original problem question “what is the winner of the Oscars Best Picture award?” I think we can confidently say that is a damn important line that mustn’t be missed. And so, I have chosen to make it the biggest line on the card. And while I was at it, I decided to drop the quotes because I felt the title was now sufficiently contrasted against the rest of the card that the quotes became superfluous.
paragraphs.name: bcd9

paragraphs.text: Do you think this redesign would have delivered the message clearly to Warren Beatty that he was holding the wrong card?
paragraphs.name: 4edf

paragraphs.text: Thanks for the comment, Nikita! There are definitely a number of ways to go about a redesign like this, so your suggestions are appreciated.
paragraphs.name: 41f4

paragraphs.text: You’re second point especially is definitely valid and something I had thought about. More so in the instance of long movie titles. That would likely need further thought to implement, for sure.

5ac6368694b9.title: What a piece of content you have produced.

paragraphs.text: What a piece of content you have produced. I enjoyed reading it all the way through. I like the way how you explained every single change you made step by step. It’s a great case study for understanding some of the general design principles. Great work.
paragraphs.name: eeb7

523f31ca3f59.title: Great example on how people like you can solve problems.

paragraphs.text: Great example on how people like you can solve problems. But I don’t think the “alignment thing” solve problems. A left handed could be in difficult reading the card.
Very clear and attractive redesign. I think you could make the margin slightly larger to address the concern you raised about left-hand thumbs obscuring the text.
You might also want to assess how readable the faint gold text will be to people with non-mainstream perception of colour or contrast. The other changes you made…
paragraphs.name: 0e33

paragraphs.text: 1. The second word, e.i. “Picture” or “Actress”, falls to the right — italic is not good here.
paragraphs.name: 94a0

paragraphs.text: 2. What about long names? In Russia we used to test interfaces, this card is an interface, with the longest name and surname: “Konstantin Konstantinopolskiy”. You will have to fix…

2b8cd0560436.title: We can add some discerning features at the back of the card for each category.

paragraphs.text: We can add some discerning features at the back of the card for each category. When the producers see it on the monitor, they might be able to spot it right away.
paragraphs.name: a05d

28150e7d2d47.title: I love the card re-design and think it is bang on.

paragraphs.text: I love the card re-design and think it is bang on. But, maybe the envelope and the back of the card need to be redesigned too, with the category emblazoned across them in a bold font.

72005246c9ac.title: I actually prefer your redesign, and there’s a much clearer explanation of why you made the design…

paragraphs.text: I actually prefer your redesign, and there’s a much clearer explanation of why you made the design choices you did. It also helped reaffirm my understanding of the C.R.A.P. principles! Great work!

6f8d1458181b.title: If we are honest we all know that most of the designers time went into everything else around the…

paragraphs.text:
If we are honest we all know that most of the designers time went into everything else around the event and some intern or a junior designer got stuck with the cards. More than likely got stuck with them the week of the deadline for all deliverables. 
The PM’s learned a great lesson about splitting the time of important resources that would have prevented this blunder.
paragraphs.name: f816

190d3638a972.title: “The award for best actress goes to *Emma Stone* in La La Land”

paragraphs.text: “The award for best actress goes to *Emma Stone* in La La Land”
Use simple, unambiguous sentences and the design of the card just doesn’t matter.
